Tomer wrote:

> My entity beans transactions are defined as "required"
> 
> How can I test something that spans multiple transactions?
> 
> If I do it from junit as an ejb client, then I cant access my entity 
> beans since they have only local interfaces.
> 
> If I do it from ejbunit, then ejbunit runs in the container and 
> therefore runs in the same transaction...

What are you trying to test? Specifically that the behavior is only 
correct when it runs across multiple transactions? or something simpler?

If you absolutely need the multiple transactions, then I'd use something 
like Cactus to test the EJBs in the real container. You'll need a remote 
EJB, like a Session Bean, to test through, since only the session bean 
will have access to the local interfaces of your entity beans.

If you just want to test logic and don't care about the transactions, 
then pull the logic out of your entity beans and put them into plain 
Java classes. Test the logic there. After that, wire the logic up to an 
entity bean as simply as possible so the entity bean is Too Simple to Break.

Without a more specific example, I can't give you any better advice.

Good luck.
